MotoGP_Fun_Facts.fact: Each rider gets his own custom-made bike. The engine is also created exclusively for them, supporting the latest top-secret technology/innovations only meant for the drivers to enjoy.
Casey Stoner is the only rider to lead every single lap of a race at the Malaysian Grand Prix. What's even better? He has done so two times (in 2007 and 2009)!
The record for the least number of No. 10 finishes in MotoGP history belongs to Valentino Rossi.
A total of 14 riders finished at the podium in the year 2011, making a record in itself.
Valentino Rossi is the most successful MotoGP rider of all time with a total of 79 career wins.
A MotoGP bike consists of multiple little computers that monitor over 500 types of data.
MotoGP suit manufacturers are now working on a type of leather which will come with an inbuilt airbag system to protect a rider's body from shock during a crash.
While turning on a corner, the contact point of a MotoGP bike's tyre is not more than a 50p coin.
Honda, Suzuki, and Yamaha combined have won all the 42 manufacturer's titles since 1974.
Gear changes take just 0.0009 seconds!
An average MotoGP bike is worth almost a seven-digit sum.
MotoGP engines are handcrafted. Thatâ€™s why MotoGP bikes are more costly than others.
A MotoGP bike has remarkably quick acceleration. It can go from 0 to 60 mph in just 2.5 seconds, which is faster than an F1 car.
The average speed of a MotoGP bike is 108 mph, which is only 10 points lower than the average speed of F1 cars (118 mph).
MotoGP riders wear soundproof helmets since a MotoGP engine produces a sound louder than 125 dB, which is ultimately louder than an orchestra.
The suit of a MotoGP rider is made up of kangaroo leather and weighs up to 4.5 kg.

MotoGP bikes contain seamless transmission, i.e., a transmission in which the next gear is already engaged before the present gear is disengaged. It helps the rider to reduce the time involved in gear changing to 0.0064 seconds.
During a race, a MotoGP rider changes gears at least 500-800 times.

MotoGP shifting, also known as reverse shifting, is a gear-shifting pattern in which the first gear is located above the neutral position, and all the other gears are below it. This is precisely opposite to the gear-shifting pattern in standard bikes.
During a race, a rider can lose up to two litres of sweat and four kg of body weight! This is almost equal to having an intense workout for three hours.
A MotoGP bike can lean up to 63 degrees while turning in a corner.
